Just a few facts:The US was 3rd to last in the Americas to abolish slavery.

The Emancipation Proclamation came abt partially because enslaved people were self-liberating by the thousands. Don’t let them tell you we just waited to be free.

#HappyJuneteenth. Today we recognize the hard-fought road that led to the emancipation of enslaved people and recommit ourselves to America’s promise of equal justice for all. Let us never lose hope that change will come.
https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/opinion/contributors/2020/06/18/what-juneteenth-means-kamala-harris-stacey-abrams-martin-luther-king/5322164002/

On #Juneteenth we remember the end of a brutal & dehumanizing system that still hurts us today. We honor our history, rejoice in the progress we’ve made & recommit to the work we still have to do. We cannot pay our ancestors back for what they did for us—we must pay it forward.

Today we must recommit to building a nation that is based on justice and to root out systemic racism wherever it exists. We must create a society that values and celebrates Black Americans. That is not the work of a single day, but of every day and every generation.
Understanding the horrors and lasting legacy of slavery is a critical step to making the changes we need in our world today, and that is why I believe we must make Juneteenth a federal holiday.

It is at once beautiful to see millions of people fighting for change, and heartbreaking that more than 150 years after the first Juneteenth celebration, Black Americans still face fundamental challenges to living in safety and dignity in this country.

Today is an opportunity to confront the systemic, institutionalized racism at the heart of America, as we see unprecedented levels of protests and activism across the country calling for an end to all forms of racism and violence toward Black Americans.
As we celebrate #Juneteenth today and commemorate the abolition of slavery in the United States, we face a transformative moment for our nation and our world that cannot be ignored.

Take every precaution to lower the risk of #COVID19 

But we are not shutting things down again http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1273986001103474695/pu/img/zY0ut_glVpF0JLEP.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1273986001103474695/pu/vid/320x450/fR6UK4CbbYKa98GY.mp4?tag=10

Today marks 155 years since June 19th, 1865, when Major General Gordon Granger announced in Galveston, TX, that the Civil War was over & enslaved people were now free. #Juneteenth is a reminder of our promise to uphold the revolutionary belief that 'all men are created equal.' https://twitter.com/NMAAHC/status/1273963106260209666 QT @NMAAHC #OTD in 1865, enslaved African Americans were notified of their freedom by Union troops in Galveston Bay, TX—two years after the Emancipation Proclamation was issued.

Known as #Juneteenth, this day is widely celebrated as the end of chattel slavery in the U.S. #APeoplesJourney http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea4Go2NX0AEmdfD.jpg
Juneteenth is a day of great historical significance and it is also a day that every American should take pride in. https://nmaahc.si.edu/blog-post/historical-legacy-juneteenth

During this time of national anguish, this #Juneteenth must be a day of reflection that moves our nation to finally confront and combat its long & shameful history of systemic racial injustice targeted at communities of color. https://www.speaker.gov/newsroom/61920

#Juneteenth stands as a beautiful celebration of freedom for African Americans. 155 years after the start of this proud tradition, it carries even greater weight, as people nationwide unite to demand justice for Black Americans killed by racial injustice & police brutality. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea4WZ7cWkAE3e49.jpg

#Juneteenth celebrates the end of slavery in the US. But it’s also a reminder that white supremacy & systemic racism remain roadblocks to racial equality & justice today. We recognize the past & present injustices that confront Black Americans every day. And we must do better. https://twitter.com/GlobeMetro/status/1273749121871028226 QT @GlobeMetro What we celebrate this Juneteenth http://w.bos.gl/zDQ006D

On #Juneteenth, let us take time to remember our history, rejoice in the progress we've made, and reflect on the enormity of the work we have left to do.

RT @janeosanders As the protests lay bare, this history isn’t known. We must expose the truths about the brutal and unjust treatment that Black communities continue to endure. Only then can we create a better future.

RT @janeosanders Today, we commemorate Juneteenth, honoring this day in 1865 that marked the end of slavery. Yet the horrors of racial injustice continued, including with the 1921 Tulsa Massacre, the worst incident of racial violence in our history.

We just introduced legislation to recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday. June 19, 1865 marks the day all enslaved people learned of their emancipation. Without question, it should be recognized with the respect of a federal holiday. #Juneteenth2020
The story of America, and the story of #Juneteenth, is a story of freedom. While we’ve had many troubled chapters along the way, I believe like Dr. King that the arc of history bends towards justice.

Today and every day, let us celebrate #BlackJoy. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea5ZDLJWoAEyaAD.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea5ZDLMWsAAipP6.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea5ZDLRXYAAtTrW.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea5ZDL3XgAA3XlP.jpg

RT @repmarkpocan A month ago, @RepBarbaraLee & I led 29 Dems demanding no increase in defense spending.

This year, we're joining @SenSanders and introducing an amendment to cut 10% from this yr's $740 billion National Defense Authorization Act.

It's time to invest in communities—not wars. https://twitter.com/SenSanders/status/1271863884060798976 QT @SenSanders Instead of spending more money on weapons of mass destruction designed to kill as many people as possible, maybe—just maybe—we should invest in improving lives right here in the United States of America. The Cruz bill will give employers and consumers the confidence they need to safely participate in the reopening process. https://www.atr.org/atr-supports-senator-cruzs-work-safe-act

Inequity runs deep in our country. It seeps throughout our education system, affects access to good-paying jobs with a living wage, affordable housing, and so many more issues. 

We must fully reckon with our country’s historic and systemic racism to enact change.

Supreme Court justices should not be legislating from the bench.
